text: for 11 years Ted Sorensen was john f
kennedy's political strategist and
confidant
he helped kennedy craft some of his most
memorable lines such as ask not what
your country can do for you ask what you
can do for your country
Sorensen also researched and co-wrote
profiles and courage the Pulitzer
prize-winning book that brought Kennedy
national fame but above all Ted Sorensen
was john f kennedy's favorite
speechwriter right cold day was probably
the most powerful speech of its kind in
many years you had a head i had a hand
in it i want to read you a few lines
from it i assume you know these lines
well i'll correct you if you're wrong
and i'd like you to pick them up where I
leave off and tell me some of the poetry
behind the politics here all right we
dare not forget today that we are the
heirs of that first revolution let the
word go forth from this time and place
to friend and foe alike torch has been
passed to the Ordnung century tempered
by war disciplined by a hard and bitter
peace proud of our ancient heritage and
unwilling to witness or permit the slow
undoing of those human rights though
which this nation has always been
committed and to which we are committed
today at home and around the world
so what are the literary antecedents I
have no doubt that I was influenced by
my reading of the Gettysburg Address as
a boy in Lincoln by reading other other
speeches of Lincoln and Jefferson
perhaps some of Winston Churchill
perhaps some from the Bible Sorenson
born in 1928 in Lincoln Nebraska
grew up in the great depression and in
the Dust Bowl days in Lincoln Nebraska
the state capital there was a wonderful
statue of Abraham Lincoln that statue of
Lincoln was in front of a slab which
contained the entire text of the
Gettysburg Address I read it many times
is that something you committed to
memory no I can't say I committed at the
memory of it I was inspired by it I read
it off and I studied it off Sorenson
earned a law degree and graduated from
the top of his class at the University
of Nebraska in 1951 soon he was
interviewing for a staff council
position with two freshman Democrat
senators in Washington and those two
were scooped Jackson of Washington State
and John F Kennedy of Massachusetts I
decided that Kennedy was the more
interest in prospect now in 1953 Senator
John Kennedy was 35 years old and knew
yourself not quite 25 young senators
were to be seen and not heard in those
days how did Senator John F Kennedy make
his mark in the 1950s John F Kennedy
made his mark in the early 1950s in two
ways one he was young good-looking
glamourous rich war hero Harvard
graduate
in his second year in the Senate he
married a beautiful glamorous woman so
the magazines and to some extent the
newspapers were full of stories about
the glamorous young senator most of
which publicity he was not seeking and
did not think was helpful he also began
drafting me to help write articles we
had an article on foreign policy in the
New York Times Sunday magazine and about
his second year and late in 53 I would
say the first year he showed me a
passage in one of his favorite books
about Senator John Quincy Adams from
Massachusetts defying all the private
interests of Massachusetts by supporting
an embargo against England
JFK thought that was a great act of
political courage to take on the
interests of his own state standing up
for the national interest he said I'd
like to write an article on this subject
I do and keep your eyes and ears open
for some other examples and I did and we
began to acquire a little file and in
the after 1954 when he became
increasingly active as a senator he had
to go to the hospital for a spinal
operation which came close to killing
him so senator Kennedy was flat on his
back in the hospital and he drafted some
notes for an idea for a short piece of
journalism yes and that chief of notes
he gave to you now are you cleared
version of America's deepest secrets
we're getting into the authorship for
profiles and courage it was his book he
was the author but I played the very
full role for which he thanked me in the
knowledge of the in the book that full
role was writing was what writing it was
research it was coordination it was
pulling together material on the
individual senators of the past and we
had selected before to be the subject of
chapters in the book of course the book
Profiles in Courage had his name on it
by John F Kennedy and rightly so and it
it won the Pulitzer Prize the following
year but it's no great secret that your
intellect your words were an integral
part of the book well I've tried to keep
it a secret it's not a secret at this
point anyway uh I'm proud to say I
played an important role but not the
determinant role that was his so is it
safe to say that John F Kennedy was the
intellectual author of the book and you
put together the bricks and mortar of
the book that's not bad
John Kennedy began thinking about
running for president in 1956 that year
he and Sorensen began touring the
country fine-tuning the Senators
speeches everything evolved during those
three plus years that we were traveling
the country together he became a much
better speaker I became a much more
equipped to write speeches for him
because day after day after day after
day he's up there on the platform
speaking and I'm sitting in the audience
listening and I find out what works and
what doesn't what do you think decided
the presidential election between
Kennedy and Nixon television in the
first television debate the first live
debate between presidential candidates
Kennedy not only looked better and
sounded better and spoke better but he
was better prepared he was more decisive
and determined in his demeanor we didn't
switch a lot of Republican votes but
Kennedy his party the Democratic Party
was the majority party in the country if
we could only gain those Democrats who
thought he was too young or too an
experienced or too Catholic in 1960
Kennedy triumphed in one of the
narrowest presidential elections in
history he was 43 years old Ted Sorensen
now his special counsel was 32 just
three months into the Kennedy presidency
in the Bay of Pigs he authorized the CIA
he had inherited to proceed with an
invasion of Cuba by Cuban exiles who had
been organized and trained and armed by
the CIA he invasions aren't usually
quiet but he had been assured by the CIA
that the people of Cuba would rise up
when they got word of this the return of
the Exiles and throw Castro out like
most of the other assurances that one
was invalid the invasion was a disaster
the CIA soon was implicated in the
fiasco in the aftermath Kennedy accepted
responsibility with a phrase that is
resonant he's said - that there's an old
Chinese saying success has a thousand
fathers and failures in Norfolk but at
that point he he stepped up to acclaimed
Parenthood which was noble of him
because the whole operation had been
conceived planned implemented and so on
by the CIA that he had not installed and
by and approved by the Joint Chiefs whom
he had not appointed Washington was
shocked no President had ever taken
responsibility for a fiasco and a
failure and the Bay of Pigs was both a
fiasco and a failure is ratings and the
public opinion polls rose causing
Kennedy to mutter that you know what
other stumbles and bumbles did he have
to commit to see it rise again
eighteen months after the Bay of Pigs
the Kennedy administration faced another
great challenge in Cuba good evening my
fellow citizens his government as
promised has maintained the closest
surveillance of the Soviet military
buildup on the island of Cuba within the
past week unmistakable evidence has
established the fact that a series of
offensive missile sites is now in
preparation on that imprisoned Island
the purpose of these bases can be none
other than to provide a nuclear strike
capability against the Western
Hemisphere no one who had not lived
through the Cuban Missile Crisis can
possibly understand the idea that for 13
days Armageddon felt at hand it was
there came a moment in the Cuban Missile
Crisis or President Kennedy had to
decide whether to attack the Soviet
missile bases in Cuba whether with
conventional weapons or conventional
force or something worse or whether to
blockade the waters around the island
what did you witness in that
decision-making moment those 13 days
were called biased or have been called
by historians most thirteen dangerous
days in the history of mankind and I
truly believe they were the Soviets had
secretly swiftly rushed these nuclear
weapons into Cuba they were capable of
reaching most parts of the United States
many parts of the hemisphere we had to
assume that they were being rushed in
secretly under cover of deception in
order to be used either used for attack
or used for nuclear blackmail trading
off Berlin or whatever and from the
first day that Kennedy called a group of
us together that would lay
called the XCOM the first option was
always a so-called surgical air strike
Kennedy was great for asking questions I
wasn't too bad at asking questions of
myself and questions revealed that the
surgical air strike a wasn't surgical at
all he would necessitated all kinds of
strikes the length and breadth of Cuba
and couldn't be sure that it would get
even even then would get all of the
missiles and that someone could still be
fired and killed hundreds of thousands
of non millions of people and so the
blockade option began to creep in
particularly when I was asked to try to
draft a high-level emissary delivered
note to Khrushchev personally warning
him so that at Bobby's insistence this
wouldn't be another Pearl Harbor in
which bombs were dropped on a small
island and innocent civilians at the
site would be killed when you went home
at night during the Cuban Missile Crisis
did you ever fear that you wouldn't see
the dawn frankly during those thirty all
thirteen of those thirteen days I was
too busy to be scared I was just working
working thinking thinking wondering what
to do sometimes I continued wondering
than worrying what to do when I got home
at night but I didn't know what to do
with a naval blockade in place the
Kennedy administration began opening
back channels to the Soviet Union
Sorensen was responsible for drafting
messages to the Soviet leader Nikita
Khrushchev I knew that any mistakes in
my letter any thing that angered or
soured Khrushchev could result in the
end of America maybe the end of the
world
so those thoughts were never far from my
mind but we had a president who remained
very calm and cool throughout and each
time he the
decision ultimately Khrushchev declared
that the missiles stationed on Cuba
would be sent back to the USSR Kennedy
in exchange loud not to invade Cuba and
to remove American nuclear missiles in
Turkey what were you doing on November
22nd 1964 all please let's not talk
about that the feeling well I really
don't want to go into that day the worst
day of my life it was the feeling of
hopelessness anger bitterness
that there was nothing that we could do
there was nothing I could do after I'd
been with him almost 11 years always
helping or was answering questions or
solving problems I couldn't do anything
that wasn't anywhere near
in the aftermath of the assassination
Sorenson wrote two popular books about
his time with Kennedy he remained deeply
involved in politics even running for
robert f kennedy's senate seat in 1970
Robert Kennedy had been a United States
Senator from New York did you feel in
some way you were taking up the mantle
frankly it was an act of hubris on my
part I did not know the state that well
I had no real constituency in the state
I was failure trying to raise money for
my campaign I learned a lot but it's not
a surprise that I lost in 1977 the
president-elect of the United States
Jimmy Carter hit you with a bit of a
bolt from the blue
did me that is true he wanted you to run
the CIA Carter asked me and I had to
make a very quick decision I did not
know whether a lawyer and a moralist was
suitable for a position that presides
over all kinds of law-breaking and
immoral activities but I wanted to be
involved I wanted to be back in the
government at a position where I could
help things have a sound and progressive
way and so I said yes I accept
but the nomination was doomed Sorensen
had been a conscientious objector thirty
years before and this fact made him a
bad fit in the eyes of some politicians
and the president who had on the
campaign trail denounced the CIA as a
national disgrace in the event left you
twisting in the wind boy did he ever
leave me twist me in the wind and he
wanted me to withdraw and I said not
till I clear my name I didn't want to
impose myself on a reluctant agency or a
reluctant Senate that would not be good
for the CIA activities in the future so
I told them that
and spoken to president-elect Carter on
my way to the hearing room and that my
nomination was being withdrawn when the
time spoke with mr. Sorenson in 2007 he
was 79 years old he was working on his
memoirs and supporting Senator Barack
Obama then seeking the Democratic
nomination for president his eyesight
had deteriorated but he continued to
often appear at speaking engagements
thank you ladies and gentlemen pay no
attention to the fact that people had to
lead me up here I don't see much but I
have more vision than the President of
the United States his speech writing a
lost art I think that frankly eloquence
in public speeches is a lost art whether
it comes from the mind and heart of the
political leader who's speaking or
whether he has speech writers was there
a trick to writing for John Kennedy a
trick
well for some reason they tried other
speechwriters and none of them ever
succeeded but that was again I I credit
those three years of traveling across
the country together and learning what
worked and what he liked what he used so
that over that long a period of time his
style and my style his standard and my
standard merged others didn't have that
all of us by virtue of our work have a
legacy we'd like to leave behind what is
yours well
my parents brought in the app to try to
make this a better world and I spent
most of my life trying I had the
extraordinary opportunity for eleven
years to try with and through a
wonderful man who shared my values and
ideals who was in a position to do
something about them
as president of the United States in
those eleven years there was no moment
of more importance to the world than the
Cuban Missile Crisis and the moment that
the president asked me to draft the
letter to Khrushchev resolving the
crisis for more than 40 years after I
left the White House my law practice
consisted mostly of international legal
matters and
in that capacity I gave some advice and
help to people like Anwar Sadat and
Nelson Mandela even had a role in
